Local human pressures influence gene flow in a hybridizing Daphnia species complex
Notes: eutrophication has allowed for sucsessful establisment of D. galeata, however the introduction of this species did not result in a hybrid swarm.

Title: Local human pressures influence gene flow in a hybridizing Daphnia species complex
Nind: 253 eggs, plus 39 "reference clones" which are from other lakes so i think the clones wouldn't count
ContextSummary: Authors simply state in the intro "we show that extensive hybridization and introgression do not necessarily result in a large and homogenous hybrid swarm." The daphnia in this study were created by multiple parentals (rather than just 1 indiv from each species making lots of hybrid babies, once) and that both species may have acted as either parent (males and females of both are creating hybrids, unlike Ben's dace, for example). They do say that conspecific mating was prefered when populations of both species were mostly equal and that they didn't see widespread introgression (of mitochondrial DNA) into either species. Looking at their q-values it seems like theres F1s and backcrosses, but I feel like that's difficult to judge with only 8 loci.

Title: Reciprocal hybrid formation of Spartina in San Francisco Bay.

Title: Draft genome sequence of wild Prunus yedoensis reveals massive inter-specific hybridization between sympatric flowering cherries.
DataLink: Available on NCBI under the accession PJQY00000000 and SRP136962
ContextSummary: This paper is a published reference genome for a species of cherry tree. The authors use the genome to prove that the trees are similar genetically and likely the results of hybridization between two species a long time ago. They say that this genus of trees may end up as a hybrid swarm as they can hybridize with one another and flower at the same time, but did not state that there currently is a hybrid swarm with the Prunus genus.

Title: Draft genome sequence of wild Prunus yedoensis reveals massive inter-specific hybridization between sympatric flowering cherries.

ContextSummary: This paper was primarily focused on creating the genome to provide context for the relationship between the hybrids and parentals.  They suggest their findings support the potential for hybridizaion to create a hybrid swarm on this island but did not test it
Notes: This paper meets the criteria (has the term in it) but may not be as useful as most of the others since the hybrid swarm is not necessarily the focus of the study

Notes: "When two distantly related genomes fuse, hybrid swarms consisting of lineages with different admixture proportions can emerge (Cockayne 1926; Stebbins 1959; Seehausen 2004). Given available ecological-niche space, hybrid swarms can act as cradle of novel, highly adapted genotypes and are therefore discussed as potential precursors of adaptive radiations (Seehausen et al. 2003; Hudson et al. 2010; Genner and Turner 2012)."

Title: Indetifying hybrids & the genomics of hybridization: Mallards & American black ducks of Eastern North America
ContextSummary: They say they did NOT find a hybrid swarm in this system, but define hybrid swarm: "If hybridization has resulted in extensive gene flow between species, then we expect to find few, if any “pure” individuals, warranting one or both species to be considered a hybrid swarm. Alternatively, if sufficient isolating mechanisms have built up between the two species, then we expect the majority of samples to be assigned with high probability to their respective species or first-generation hybrids (F1), and little evidence of generational backcrosses (≥F2). Such a scenario would be consistent with the reinforcement hypothesis in which taxa retain species boundaries during secondary contact due to viability limitations of any potential hybrids (Servedio & Noor, 2003)."
Notes: Expansion of the mallard population is due to a combination of natural invaders and domestic ducks

Title: Identifying hybrids & the genomics of hybridization: Mallards & American black ducks of Eastern North America.
ContextSummary: Did not find evidence to support hybrid swarm between these duck species despite observing extensive hybridization.  They say this is because it takes minimal backcrossing to make offspring closest to parental lineages again.
Notes: Mallards are split into two groups, the native ducks and the "game farm mallards".  I am confused about the Nhybridgen and Nbackcrossgen answers

ContextSummary: This is another example of a paper where the authors hypothetically say that their system could become a hybrid swarm, but don't mention it again. In this paper, they state that if two populations hybridize, with one being common and the other rare, then either the rare population/species will go extinct or a hybrid swarm will form. So this is also another example of authors using hybid swarm to mean genetic swamping, and dancing around the terms genetic and demographic swamping.

They took a bunch of eggs from the insects and brought them to the lab then tried crossing them. They found no strong selection against production of hybrids in the lab, but stated that because there's no hybrid swarm found in the wild, there must be some form of selection or reproductive barrier that exists in the wild to discourage formation of hybrids. So this sounds like another paper saying "it could become a hybrid swarm, but isn't currently"

They show that their data is not significantly different from the HYBRIDLAB hybrid swarm model, which is basically them saying that their species seems similar to a hybrid swarm. In this case, it seems like they're describing a hybrid swarm as populations with tons of backcrossing (gene flow) between them.

Title: Genetic, morphological, and ecological characterization of a hybrid zone that spans a migratory divide.
ContextSummary: This hybrid zone was described as NOT being a hybrid swam. The genomic cline was very steep, and few hybrids were found. However, backcrosses were present, and many studies seem to have described the presence of any backcrosses as a hybrid swarm. The term was once again uncited. Interestingly, they said that any BC2s and beyond were classified as parentals, likely because of low power for detecting hybrids. But that means individuals that may have had around 0.75 of one ancestry source were considered parentals, which is a little too generous, in my opinion.

But these just give background on the 2 plant species hybridizing, not the term hybrid swarm. Essentially, we see only backcrosses and F1s in this system, not continual hybridization.

DataLink: just figures and tables, seemingly no raw data and no doi
ContextSummary: Found evidence to suggest these species do not make up a hybrid swarm, because of the limited levels of introgression between their focal species.
Notes: The poaka "self-introduced" from Australia, and their expansion through New Zealand is blamed on deforestation, which is why they said it was anthropogenic

Title: Rapid formation of distinct hybrid lineages after secondary contact of two fish species (Cottus sp.).
ContextSummary: Used an existing hybrid swarm to  analyze the invasion and expansion of the hybrids into new territories

Title: Rapid formation of distinct hybrid lineages after secondary contact of two fish species (Cottus sp.).
ContextSummary: The paper focuses on hybrids that have expanded into new areas of the river system, promoted by anthropogenic disturbance. They state that 3 hybrid lineages have formed where the hybrid populaitons are differentiating from one another and from the parentals, as they expand into the new environments. The authors state that the source of this was a hybrid swarm between the two species, that consisted of lots of backcrossing and produced many hybrid genotypes, which selection was able to act upon to allow the hybrids with the highest fitness to thrive in these new environments. So this is another case where hybrid swarm means a lot of backcrossing, not continual breeding between hybrids, as the latter is considered the formation of a hybrid lineage.
